Executive Summary

This document was developed to comply with the Environmental Protection AgencyÂ¿s (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) II, under Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 CFR Part 68. An outline of the RMP is provided in Figure ES-1.  Processes covered under this regulation at the Water Treatment Plant (WTP) include chlorine systems. 

FIGURE ES-1 OUTLINE OF RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
 
To meet the regulation requirements, this binder contains useful information on the chlorine system. The technical information herein may be used as a training reference in initial and recurring operator and maintenance training. Training on process fundamentals, operations, and maintenance, coupled with the recommended process modifications discussed below, will reduce the potential hazards to plant personnel and the surrounding community.
An Emergency Response Program and an Incident Investigation Program are included. These two programs should be an integral part of both initial and recurring training.
A Risk Management Plan (Plan), as required by the EPA, is included at the end of the main body of this document. It consists of a summary of data elements that must be submitted to the EPA which will eventually be uploaded onto a public access data base. The Plan has an Executive Summary that follows a required EPA format, and is intended to inform the public of the WTP's proactive stance toward protection of the environment and the surrounding community.

Hazard Assessment
The Hazard Assessment is comprised of a Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenario each for the chlorine system, as well as a 5-Year Accident H

istory for the same. The Hazard Assessment was conducted as an initial screening procedure as part of determining into which Program Level (I, II, or III) the WTP falls. 
Residences lie within the EPA-defined endpoint concentrations of WTP's Worst-Case releases. Therefore, the plant is ineligible for Program I. Because Texas public utilities are currently excluded from Program III, the WTP is included in Risk Management Program II.  

Worst Case Scenario
The Worst Case Scenario was defined as a ton container (2,000 pounds) of chlorine being released by a catastrophic event within 10 minute duration. Mitigation factor of 0.55 was allowed for this process due to the enclosure covering it. This scenario was developed and modeled using the EPA approved dense gas dispersion model DEGADIS 2.1. The toxic endpoint for chlorine was determined to be 1.55 miles.

Alternative Release Scenario
The Alternative Release Scenario of chlorine was also modeled using DEGADIS. Source term estimation of approximately 175 pounds released was derived from a scenario of pressurized flexible tubing failure. The dispersion model estimated the 3 ppm chlorine footprint to extend to 0.26 miles.

5 Year Accident History
No accidents have ever occurred at the plant involving either onsite or offsite consequences within the last five years.

Management Program
The Management Program consists of the Document Management System described below.

Document Management System
A Document Management System was established to attribute responsibility for the development, implementation, and maintenance of the Risk Management Program. The Program must be updated every three years, or any time a covered process undergoes a physical or administrative modification.  The Document Management System is largely a function of the Risk Management Program Team, listed below in Table ES-2.

Risk Management Program Team
The following members are responsible for the Risk Management Program development, implementation, and

maintenance. The Water Treatment Plant Superintendent has the ultimate responsibility.

Table ES-2  Cedar Park WTP Risk Management Program Team

Position /Expertise
Water Treatment Plant Superintendent
Senior Operator
Operator
Operator
Fire Chief, City of Cedar Park
Fire Marshal, City of Cedar Park

Prevention Program
The Prevention Program is more appropriately entitled the Accidental Release Prevention Program.  It is comprised of Safety Information, Hazard Review, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Incident Investigation, and 	Compliance Audit procedures.  Each has an entire chapter devoted to it in this RMP, and is described in more detail below.

Safety Information
Safety Information is divided between Chemical Safety Information, and Process Safety Information.  Each is described below.

Chemical Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data is provided in this section to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazards and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of each regulated substance. This information was compiled from numerous sources, and is intended to be a one-stop source for the reader seeking data on these substances. The physical data will provide useful information in the inevitable event the plant processes are modified, thereby requiring revisited dense gas dispersion modeling.

Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information was meticulously compiled on each system studied. Specifications are collocated in one place for easy reference. Details such as Maximum Intended Inventory, Safe Upper and Lower Temperatures, Safe Upper and Lower Pressures, and Codes and Standards Used to Design, Build and Operate the Process are provided in this section. Used as a training reference, together with the Process Schematics located in the Appendix, the reader will readily understand the function and operation of the chlorine system.

Hazard Review
A Hazard Review was conducted for the chlorin

e system. The team consisted of facility management, process operating and maintenance experts, outside process design engineers, and consultants knowledgeable in the Hazard Review process itself. The Hazard Review technique used was a hybrid Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), in the form of a "What If" analysis. The "What If" was developed from HAZOP experience at similar treatment facilities.

Recommendations
The result of the Hazard Review is a set of recommendations for the plant to implement. The Rule under 40 CFR 68.50 requires the City of Cedar Park to ensure that problems identified are "resolved in a timely manner."  For those items that can not be promptly resolved, it is recommended that a schedule be developed that addresses those issues, with personnel responsibility assigned for each.  
Please note that these are not the recommendations of Camp Dresser & McKee Inc.  Rather, they are Plant recommendations developed by the Hazard Review Team with a consensus from all team members.  CDM's role was simply to facilitate the Hazard Review process. 
The results of the Hazard Review were tabulated and a summary of the recommendations is provided below. 

Administrative and Operational Recommendations
Vendor audits were recommended to verify quality assurance and quality control on chlorine packaging. The City of Cedar Park should be interested in container hydrostatic testing and pre-shipment inspection. Look for inspection reports from appropriate oversight agencies. If at all possible, it was recommended to investigate contractual control over the vendor. In other words, use contract language and specifications to ensure the arrival of safe ton containers along with high-quality chlorine. Hold the supplier responsible for liability and monetary damages associated with defective ton containers and/or chlorine.
Especially important is to supervise the chlorine supplier during unloading procedure. Visually inspect his equipment prior to unloading. Ensure ton

container caps are in place before handling containers.
Another operational remainder is to always ensure lines are evacuated prior to disconnecting any chlorination equipment.

Training Recommendations
Certain hazards reviewed can be mitigated through training. The following were highlighted during Hazard Review as particularly important to operating/maintenance personnel, and the community.
The first, and most general, is to verify training on plant operating and maintenance procedures. These procedures were developed in conjunction with the plant operating and maintenance staff and should incorporate all of the safety concerns that arose during the Hazard Review.
Ensure operators understand the hazard associated with exposing oil, grease, petroleum products, or other combustibles to chlorine gas. Use only non-reactive, approved lubricants on the chlorination system. Use good housekeeping in the area, and store no combustibles around the chlorination equipment.
Finally, ensure that the CityÂ¿s Emergency Response policy is implemented and the staff trained. If a leak, occurs the person discovering the leak should ensure the plant siren is activated, then dial 911, implement two-way walkie-talkie for fire department notification and communicate the emergency. Then, evacuate the plant proceeding to the predetermined staging area for roll call, decontamination, and medical treatment.

Recommendations for Further Study
The following recommendations were tabled for further study. These studies should compare various configurations, as well as equipment manufacturers and models, with both economic and non-economic costs.
The WTP Superintendent suggested that a potential confined space issue might arise if the building were enclosed to accommodate emergency scrubbing. The Team agreed that this issue should be addressed as part of the scrubber design.
The Team recommended looking at 911 for emergency notification and to implement two-way walkie-talkie for fire department

notification. This allows a direct dial of emergency response officials in case of chlorine leak detection.
A plant siren is recommended that will be audible to all facility personnel whether in or out of doors. This siren may be directly coupled to the leak system, or be manually activated or both.
The WTP Superintendent recommended a small weather station (wind vane and anemometer) in lieu of windsock. The City Fire Chief also prefers this arrangement. Software exists to automatically transmit wind direction and speed to the emergency response officials.
The Hazard Review Team recommended a backup power generator, although it was not a hazard-driven recommendation. The generator capacity should be determined as a result of a proper load distribution and need analysis assuming a hypothetical power outage.
Consider implementation of a computerized Maintenance Management System (MMS).
The last items recommended for further consideration are redundant leak detectors with sensor self-test features. These incorporate built-in chlorine gas generators for better calibration.

Operating Procedures
Chlorination System Operating Procedures have been amended for the WTP. They provide system descriptions, specifications, and operating procedures for the chlorine system. Procedures include Initial Startup; Normal, Temporary, Abnormal, Emergency Shutdowns and Operations; Startup Following a Shutdown or Major Change; and Consequences of Deviation. Also included are Troubleshooting Procedures.

Training 
Training is required by EPA to be included in the Risk Management Program. A program has been developed with guidelines on how to conduct regular and structured plant training. Training Record Forms are included with the Program for the required training documentation. Additionally, a Training Record has been compiled and included for all affected personnel associated with the covered processes.

Maintenance
A Maintenance Program has been developed with associated documentation fo

rms. Sound preventive maintenance will reduce potential hazards to personnel onsite, as well as to the off-site public. State and federal regulators will most surely expect to see documentation and recordkeeping associated with the Maintenance Program. 

Incident Investigation
An Incident Investigation Program has been developed. The EPA has established strict guidelines to follow in the aftermath of any release involving either the chlorine system. The Incident Investigation Program outlines key milestones that must be accomplished within 24 hours of any covered incident, and the actions that must occur subsequently. Ultimately, it is desired that the plant learn from the incident and take action to prevent similar incidents in the future. Incident Investigation Report Forms are included, and must be maintained for a minimum of five years after each incident.

Compliance Audits
Internal Compliance Audits must be conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in this document. The WTP Superintendent must certify that the Risk Management Program team has evaluated compliance with the provisions of the Program, and verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed. Audit Report Forms are provided, the two most recent of which must always be maintained. This means that in the year 2010, the Compliance Audit Report for the year 2004 may be discarded.

Emergency Response Program
The Emergency Response Program is included as part of the Risk Management Program, in case a significant release ever occurs. As in all the above programs, it is important to review this program regularly. The Rule, 40 CFR 68.95 requires training for all employees "in relevant procedures" of the Emergency Response Program.
It is recommended that training on the specific plant procedures take place upon initial employment and every three years thereafter, as with most of the other RMP training programs.  Other training recomme
ndations, i.e., OSHA 8, 24, and 40 hour training are discussed in the Emergency Response Program as appropriate to the level of response.
